It was the dumbest decision they ever made.

Comment: JPow drew a line and said rates will not go down no matter what. Markets responded negatively when the Trump administration threatened to remove him by announcing they were “looking into legal channels,” so it’s clear the market makers want to keep JPow in place through this term.   A recession would just make things generally cheaper so you are correct that it would be a buyer’s market for the richest.   Thankfully there’s a horde of current homeowners entrenched with sub 3% rates, so even if one parent loses a job, their mortgage is fixed and should be easy to handle on one income. This means the real estate market isn’t going to flip to corporate:PE-owned if we do head into a recession.

Author: UeckerisGod

Comment: That may be part of it, but assuming it's just for personal enrichment is too narrow. These people have an ideology, and it is that the US should be an autarky. Anytime you completely undo the economy you are doing shock therapy, and that means people lose their jobs and the economy tumbles because everything has to be burned down then built back up.   Now to their credit, the Trump Administration is under no illusion that Americans are going to like it. They've been warning the people to prepare for higher prices or months now; it hasn't just been Trumps dolls comment. On the campaign trail Musk openly admitted that gutting the government may contribute to a recession, and I think Homan told a reporter Americans should just stop eating certain foods that can't be made in America (oh boy I can't wait until this reaches chocolate). This doesn't go that far because Trump was still promising to lower prices on the campaign trail, and after he was elected, then said it wasn't happening.   Now this just goes back to shock therapy. It hurts, but a lot of the time the people are willing to put up with it if it resolves the fundamental issues with the economy. That happened in the Eastern Bloc like in Poland or Czechia, which now have rapidly caught up to their Western Brethren, as well as currently in Argentina, where Milei's policies have tamed inflation. Of course, this is doing shock therapy in reverse. The US is in a unique position where it has a lot of resources and can be an autarky unlike a lot of countries, but we're going to be poorer for it in the long run. Things will cost more and we will make less money.   Anyway, the point is, the tariffs are meant to force everything to be made in America, as much as possible. A lot of companies have announced investments of new factories into America, from Nvidia to Maersk as a result, but many others have not. It will take time to see if this is actually effective, likely he's quietly keeping the IRA and Infrastructure bill to pay for a lot of it, though he's also kneecapping renewables to bring back coal and gas.   Even if it works, any economics student can see the result coming a mile away. Cutting off trade is a supply shock, even if everything is made in America it will still cost more even if wages are minimum. They keep claiming that we will have "good paying" factory jobs, but if there's a recession to force this to happen I fail to see how it would be good paying, especially when coupled with inflation from the supply shock. We will go through a lot of pain and burn all of our international standing to come out the other end working factory jobs for subpar wages and paying even higher prices.

Comment: A component of the GDP is net exports. Net exports are exports minus imports (a trade surplus or deficit). Every U.S. company was scrambling to import as much as they could before the tariffs got worse and exports declined. The net effect of this was a massive increase in the trade deficit in Q1, dragging down GDP. So yes, it was largely caused by Trump’s tariff policies.  The latest projections expect the GDP to be about half of what it was last year so there’s plenty of additional downside possible.   The other GDP components:  Consumption: consumer spending is about 70% of the GDP. Consumers were still spending in Q1, but imagine what will happen when this slows down.   Investment: capital investment to grow or create new business cratered given all the business and global economic uncertainties.   Government spending: actually rose in Q1  increasing the federal deficit even more, even though DOGE and Trump will claim otherwise.

Comment: You’re kind of undermining your point by claiming Harris and Trump are the same. They’re similar on exactly one issue, which is supporting Israel militarily, something both parties have agreed on basically forever. On every single other issue, they’re polar opposites.  Should the Democrats stop trying to appeal to mythical moderate Republicans and actually try to court progressives? Of course they should. But when progressives stay home because they refuse to acknowledge the big picture, what do you expect Dem leadership to do? You told them they lost your vote, which means in political terms, your support is too conditional to be relied upon. You had a choice between center-left and fascist, and you said “I don’t like either of these choices” and stayed home, then acted like you made some high-minded principled decision in doing so.  There was no time for a presidential primary. We can go back and forth about whose fault that was and how it could have been avoided, but that’s not productive until after the election. You and voters like you chose to treat the general election like a primary, and Trump won. Now we’re all fucked, probably for the rest of our lives if we’re Millennials or older. I hope your principles are a great comfort to you whenever you stop to think about how much they’ve cost us all, ten years from now.

Comment: >Make them earn your fucking vote.  They did earn people's votes - just look at the differences in the results of their policies and Republican policies.  Americans in blue states live longer than those in red states.  Here’s a study from 2020 studying the link between Democrat policies and increased lifespan: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8053253/  Americans in the states with the longest life expectancy live about 5 years longer than those with the lowest life expectancy.  The states with the highest life expectancy have long histories of voting for liberals.  Here’s an article about another study from 2022: https://www.usnews.com/news/health-news/articles/2022-10-31/liberal-state-policies-tied-to-lower-mortality-rates-study-shows    Blue states give back more money to the federal government than they receive, while red states take more than they give.  [https://time.com/7222411/blue-states-are-bailing-out-red-states/](https://time.com/7222411/blue-states-are-bailing-out-red-states/)  Red states are on average more dependent on financial help from the federal government compared to blue states.  If the federal coffers vanished tomorrow, then blue states would be better at financially supporting themselves without welfare.   Salaries are on average higher in the more liberal parts of America than the more conservative ones. [https://www.forbes.com/advisor/business/average-salary-by-state/](https://www.forbes.com/advisor/business/average-salary-by-state/)   Lists of the most educated states show that blue states on average have more educated people than red states.  https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/slideshows/the-10-most-educated-states-in-the-us?onepage  Meanwhile, red states that can’t keep up in education are losing jobs because their students aren’t educated enough for them.  https://ocpathink.org/post/independent-journalism/public-school-failures-have-ripple-effects-in-workforce    Red states have more murders than blue states: https://www.thirdway.org/report/the-21st-century-red-state-murder-crisis.    The last time the US had a budget surplus was in 2001, when Democrat President Bill Clinton was leaving office.  Under the leadership of Republican George W. Bush, the US began running a deficit.  The last budget passed by Bush was for 2009, which was passed in 2008 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009\_United\_States\_federal\_budget).  Bush’s 2008 budget resulted in a sudden spike in the deficit from $0.45 trillion to $1.42 trillion, just in time for Democrat Obama’s first year in office.  By 2016, Obama was able to lower the deficit to $0.59 trillion.  By 2019, under the leadership of Republican Donald Trump, the deficit had gone back up to $0.98 trillion.  The deficit then spiked to $3.13 trillion in 2020 due to Covid.  As of 2024, Democrat Biden had brought the deficit back down to $1.83 trillion.  The pattern is clear - Democrats are better for the US federal treasury than Republicans.  https://fiscaldata.treasury.gov/americas-finance-guide/national-deficit/  Of the four presidents who had the most job creation under their leadership, three of them were Democrats: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jobs\_created\_during\_U.S.\_presidential\_terms.  When Trump was elected, Republicans wanted him to keep Biden’s Inflation Reduction Act because of the jobs Biden’s policies had created.  https://www.cnn.com/2024/11/15/climate/climate-law-trump-republicans/index.html      Conservatives claim that they want to protect children from predators, yet they won’t pass laws to stop child marriage - which opens a pathway for pedophiles to legally do what they wish to children.  https://apnews.com/article/child-marriage-west-virginia-bill-defeated-4d822a23b5ffd70f5370a36cc914cfb0.  In contrast, Democrats are moving ahead with laws designed to stop child marriage.  https://www.cbsnews.com/detroit/news/gov-gretchen-whitmer-signs-legislation-to-ban-child-marriage-in-michigan/.  Republican politicians turn out to be sexual predators in substantially higher numbers than Democrats, and Republican statements that people like drag queens are sexual predators have been found to be untrue: https://www.whoismakingnews.com/.

Comment: I believe I did my bit. And we have been utterly failed by our party.  I believe that patriotism is virtue of the vicious.  We will blame anyone but the people responsible.  That why Chuck Schumer is saying "we're focusing on winning and we are".... in the middle of the collapse of the USA as a political and economic superpower to an isolationist republic committing economic suicide and losing our place as the world reserve currency.   It is disingenuous to say if only everyone who didn't vote had showed up, we would have won.  We don't know that.... not by a long shot... We ran that bad of a campaign.   A stay the course "I'm my own candidate that wouldn't do  anything substantially different from my predecessor" campaign in a change election....we trotted out the endorsement of McCain for God's sake that man was a literal boogeyman to those of us old enough to remember him.   We ran as republican lite which wins fewer progressives, less independents and almost 0 republican votes.   Of those that did show up, Trump won... I know he didn't win by a landslide but it was the first popular vote win for a republican in 20 years. I mean a truly embarrassing route.  Yet still, we have carville and Pelosi doing everything they can to sideline AOC, the squad, and Bernie. Holding on to power and fundraising is the only thing the current leadership seems interested in.   You guys are all coming at me because I'm uninterested in allowing the party to pass the buck on this.  I was a delegate for Clinton, I voted and supported dem candidates in the heart of blood red Texas for 27 years.  Our party has failed us, and to fix that, we have to direct our angst at the right people and demand better.   Not point fingers and say oh women let us down, or Latinos let us down or college educated men let us down.   They never owed us their vote....it was is and always will be the job of the party and ultimately the candidate to earn that vote. Winning is the first job of a political candidate. If they don't do that, they failed period.
Author: Chainsawjack

Comment: And yet we are under no obligation to help select which product we buy.  Voting is a right and even a moral obligation to me but it isn't a legal duty.  Still i like your analogy. But I don't Think it invalidates the point.    To whit we can liken this to car insurance which we all are compelled to buy, but in a competitive market it's the various insurance companies job to make the case that we should buy it from them,  right.   And if one of those companies fails and goes out of business who's to blame for that?  If I'm a person who was supposed to buy insurance but didn't then I will suffer the legal and financial repercussions of that choice (like the voter who lives in a world they chose to have no say in), but i can't be said to be directly responsible for the failure of that company can I?  Because even if i had bought car insurance there is no guarantee I would have gone with that company or if I did, that i would have been enough to save it.
Author: Chainsawjack

Comment: We don't have a pure democracy and never did.   In a two party system the parties are responsible for shaping and molding candidates and elections.   The people were presented with only two options.  The parties are responsible for the selection of those options and the messaging of those campaigns.  It's all fine and good to say weas a country chose wrong but my actual goal is to force our party to  make changes to ensure we choose right more consistently.  Blaming low turnout doesn't get us there.  The parties running better campaigns would improve turnout.  We don't know for sure that 100 percent voter participation would have changed the result at all.   The campaign was that bad
Author: Chainsawjack

Comment: I don’t disagree with a word you said. Having said that, in terms of simply defining the mindset of the country before Trump was re-elected, I think all of that is a bit above the heads of the average person. Sure the rate of inflation slowing is nice, but the damage of previous bouts of inflation had already been done. If I can’t afford anything already, I’m not exactly going to be kicking myself with joy if you tell me the rate at which things become even more unaffordable has slowed. I still can’t afford to live. Folks were wanting either prices to decrease altogether, or for wages and earnings to go up substantially. Neither of which happened.   Again, not blaming Biden. And I agree Trump was an obviously terrible choice. I just think this attempt to try and disprove peoples feelings about the economy is missing the point and is counterproductive.
Author: anythingfordopamine

Comment: Probably more like massive wealth inequality, and the fact that things like housing, health care, and child care have become unaffordable to so many regular people due the destruction of the middle class.   Of course, those things started long before Biden, but the inflation that happened on his watch exacerbated those concerns and made a lot of people truly realize that they aren't as well-off as they thought they were. Those things are real concerns, not "Republican propaganda."   Now, why all those people thought *Trump* was the guy to fix those problems, that's something I will never understand as long as I live, as he is the least credible person imaginable on this topic. But Democrats are not doing themselves any favors by thinking that people's dissatisfaction was all made-up
Author: IAmTheNightSoil

Comment: What's even more frustrating to me is that we've seen time and time again that the way to push politics and politicians and a party to be more leftward/rightward is by voting consistently for the left/right-most viable candidate, and that staying home accomplishes the opposite. Even if you lose a primary, a strong showing still advances the issues those candidates/voters cared about. Bernie Sanders accomplished more at advancing left/progressive/etc issues in his two primary losses than the Greens have in any of their Presidential runs going all the way back to Nader in 2000.  The Right wing figured this out, and that's why they not only haven't entertained any third party runs since the 90s, they've *actively supported third party runs on the left to split the vote because they know it helps them win.*
Author: The_Lost_Jedi
